passages.text: EQUITY: EQUITY STRATEGY
All eyes on the US NFP report. Another weak report the coming week could dent risk- appetite, in our view

With NVDA results out of the way and in- line US Core PCE on Friday, all eyes will be on US' August NFP report in the coming week. July's NFP report was clearly weak and another weak report will likely provide fodder to macro- bears, in our view. Nomura's US economists expect \(+85k\) headline gains (vs consensus' \(75k\) ) and the unemployment rate (UE) at \(4.3\%\) (in line with consensus), which we think should not unnerve equity investors. However, in a scenario, where the NFP report is clearly weaker (4.3% UE), we think risk- appetite could take a hit as growth slowdown concerns might outweigh the Fed rate- cut theme. Price action in US Al/tech stocks - a major support for indices - has been shaky again this past week with DELL and MRVL stock prices weak after results on Friday in US hours. We note that the last time we witnessed two straight misses were the July and August 2024 US jobs report when risk appetite did take a hit ( \(\sim 8.5\%\) and \(10\%\) drawdown in the S&P and MXASJ, respectively within one month). This was despite the market pricing in an aggressive set of Fed rate cuts as signalled by falling short- end US bond yields (Fig. 1). Tech/momentum stocks saw an unwinding, too (also amplified by Yen strength and NKY plunge in Aug'24), and underperformance relative to Value (Fig. 2). Thus, if the NFP report is indeed quite weak, we think tech/momentum stocks may be more vulnerable. In this scenario, in Asia- ex- Japan, we would be most concerned about Taiwan and Korea tech/momentum stocks. For India, we remain concerned due to ongoing tensions with the US which has dented the narrative on India stocks (EU considering secondary sanctions on Russia's oil related exports is another risk to monitor for India, in our view). However, we remain tactically positive on HK/China stocks where we think strong liquidity and stable US- China relations can continue to support a further re- rating of stocks, and reiterate our view that "bubble" fears are premature. If anything, HK/China stocks (especially domestic, laggards) may get some additional support from potential re- allocation flows should there be some profit- taking in tech stocks in the region.

On a multi- month view, as we have noted in the past (refer Asia- ex- Japan Equity Strategy - Lessons from the past six Fed rate cut cycles): Stock market outlook will matter on whether Fed rate cuts are coming due to a very weak US economy (i.e., US recession) or due to disinflationary pressures. In this regard, we think revisiting equities performance during the 2001 vs 1998 Fed rate cut cycle is instructive (Fig. 3 - 4). The 1998 rate cut cycle was caused by a financial turmoil that coincided with a \(\sim 19\%\) drawdown in the S&P before eventually culminating into the tech- bubble of 2000- 01 (Fig. 3). In contrast, the 2001 Fed rate cuts were driven by the dot- com bust, coinciding with a mild recession, with stocks posting steep declines driven by tech/growth stocks - the same ones that had powered the S&P higher earlier (Fig. 4). For further discussion, refer Asia Monday Morning Espresso - Is this 2001 redux or 1998 (or neither)?. Our baseline view at this juncture is that the US economy will avoid a recession, while we remain optimistic on the prospects of the AI thematic (although occasional intermittent valuations over- runs are always possible).

Foreigners were heavy net- sellers of EM Asia- ex China stocks for the second straight week (- USD4.2bn w- w), refer Fig. 5. Barring Indonesia (which was likely driven by one off index rebalancing flows), all major markets posted net- outflows, with India once again posting heavy net- outflows (USD2.4bn w- w, including preliminary outflows from Friday). Offshore- listed India ETFs have also sustained five straight weeks of net- outflows, based
Research Associates Asia ex- Japan Equity Strategy Ankit Yadav - NSFSPL

on our aggregations. The INR also hit a new low against the USD. We remain concerned on India equities, as we see scope for some more multiple contraction amid elevated US- India tensions and valuations. Korea and Taiwan posted a second straight week of foreign net- outflows. However, US- listed China- focussed ETFs posted net- inflows for the seventh straight week, with buying picking up w- w suggesting better foreign investor sentiment, in our view. Meanwhile, in global flows, continuing the theme from past several weeks, offshore European- focussed ETFs posted net- outflows yet again (fifth straight week), while US- focussed offshore- listed ETFs posted net inflows for the sixth straight week.

2Q25 Asia ex- Japan earnings: Consensus earnings downgrades at index level 2Q25 earnings season in Asia is almost coming to an end, with about \(90\%\) of the MSCI AeJ companies having reported thus far. So far, our bottom- up aggregated data show overall MSCI AeJ FY25E consensus earnings are down \(- 1.2\%\) QTD (but flat w- w), refer Fig. 6. In terms of major companies that reported this past week (predominantly in HK/China), in general, China consumer and tech earnings have held up better so far in this 2Q25 earnings season. In terms of major companies that reported this past week Beat/Strong Guidance: Trip.com, Innovent Biologics, Shennan Circuits, Alibaba. In- line/Mixed Results: PDD Holdings, ANTA Sports, China Resources Land, Maybank. Miss/Softer Guidance: Meituan, Ping An Insurance, Li Auto, KE Holdings, Public bank.

Coming week, the prime focus of market participants will be on the US August NFP report as discussed above. Nomura's US economists expect headline job gains of \(85k\) (slightly higher than consensus' \(+75k\) ). They also think there could be a modest upward revision to July NFP. They believe that the unemployment rate, which has been emphasized by policymakers as a reliable measure to gauge labor market strength, likely ticked up by one- tenth to \(4.3\%\) in August (same as consensus), and expect wage growth (AHE) at \(0.3\%\) m- m (same as consensus). Overall, our US team continues to believe that the labor market is losing momentum and the shifting balance of risks to the Fed's dual mandate, is likely to lead to a 25bp cut at the September meeting. However, contained layoffs and few signs of acute labor market stress are likely to limit aggressive easing, in their view. Apart from this, there is some Fedspeak where Fed officials (including Williams) are expected to speak at separate events. In hard data, JOLTS job opening likely fell to 7370k in July (vs 7437k in June), bringing down the VU ratio to 1.02; ISM Manufacturing index likely edged up to 48.7 (NMR estimate slightly below consensus) in August; ISM Services Index also likely ticked up to 51.2 (NMR estimate above consensus) in August.

In Asia, some focus would be on the remainder of the 2Q earnings season with only fewer companies left to report. In hard data, our China economists expect the RatingDog Mfg PMI (formerly Caixin Manufacturing PMI), which surveys more SMEs and exporters in the eastern coastal region of China, to remain subdued at 49.8 in August (same as consensus). Elsewhere in Asia - the BNM will hold its policy meeting and our economists expect no change in rates after the 'pre- emptive' 25bp cut at its previous MPC meeting. In other events, Shanghai Cooperation Summit is currently being held in China where President Putin, PM Modi and President Xi are expected to meet. There could be some spotlight on China's Sep 3 military parade with some market participants expecting sentiment towards China equities to remain positive ahead/into the event.
Fig. 1: In a scenario of another weak NFP report coming week we think risk- appetite may take a hit - similar to what happened during July-Sep 2024 when we had two straight NFP headline misses...
Fig. 2: ...that episode also saw an unwinding of tech and momentum stocks and relative outperformance of value and laggards
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P., MSCI, Nomura research

Fig. 3: 1998 rate cut cycle: A very short rate cut cycle driven by a financial turmoil from a multitude of factors such as Asian Financial Crisis, Russian devaluation of the rouble and the collapse of the LTCM. However, as a US recession was avoided, stocks managed to eventually do well, after being down into rate cuts
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P., Nomura research

Fig. 4: 2001 rate cut cycle: Bond yields and stocks peaked ahead of the start of rate cuts driven by dot.com bust coinciding with a mild recession. Despite only a mild recession, stocks were significantly down as starting valuations were on the higher side, in our view
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P., Nomura research
Fig. 5: Foreign net flows into equities

Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P., Nomura research; based on latest available data on 29 August 2025; India flows include prelim flows of Friday; EM ex-China includes EM Asia ex-China, South Africa, Brazil, and Turkey; Turkey and Japan flows are usually delayed by a week. ETF flows data are preliminary based on information available at the time of publishing, and therefore subject to revisions next week.
Fig. 6: Consensus earnings revisions during the recent reporting season (since the end of Jun-25)
Source: MSCI, FactSet, Nomura research. Note: Bottom-up estimates for MSCI companies using free float-adjusted earnings and constant currency conversions.

STOCKSA rating of 'Buy', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to outperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Neutral', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to perform in line with the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Reduce', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to underperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Suspended', indicates that the rating, target price and estimates have been suspended temporarily to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies. Securities and/or companies that are labelled as 'Not rated' or shown as 'No rating' are not in regular research coverage. A 'Bullish' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to outperform the Benchmark during the next 12 months. A 'Neutral' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to perform in line with the Benchmark during the next 12 months. A 'Bearish' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to underperform the Benchmark during the next 12 months. Sectors that are labelled as 'Not rated' or shown as 'N/A' are not assigned ratings. Benchmarks are as follows: United States: S&P 500; Europe: Dow Jones STOXX 600; Global Emerging Markets (ex- Asia): MSCI Emerging Markets ex- Asia. Japan/Asia ex- Japan: Sector ratings are not assigned.

A Target Price, if discussed, indicates the analyst's forecast for the share price with a 12- month time horizon, reflecting in part the analyst's estimates for the company's earnings. The achievement of any target price may be impeded by general market and macroeconomic trends, and by other risks related to the company or the market, and may not occur if the company's earnings differ from estimates.
